results.title: The Lord of the rings: the return of the king
results.creator_credit: Peter Jackson, Fran Walsh, Barrie M Osborne, New Line Cinema and Wingnut Films
results.brief_description: Final part of Peter Jacksons iconic adaptation of J R R Tolkien’s fantasy epic, “The Lord of the rings” trilogy sees the interleaved narrative threads of parts one and two drawn to closure. As per the other instalments (filmed simultaneously), Jackson goes to meticulous lengths to bring Tolkien’s fantastical vision to the screen by building extensive sets in his native New Zealand and by employing a slew of gifted special effects artists. Still divided, the fellowship continue their separate quests; Frodo and Sam head towards Mount Doom led by the duplicitous Gollum; Aragon, Legolas and Gimli fight numerous battles and engage the services of a ghost army; Merry and Pippin drift in and out of trouble. With unrivalled flourish, Jackson invokes all the necessary thrills of an adventure picture, with his awesome CGI wizardry and stupendous set pieces. But whilst the ambitious battle scenes are masterful, the film lacks satisfying arcs (as part 3, perhaps by necessity, its all climaxes) and is let down by an interminable ending. Nevertheless Jackson creates a grand spectacle, setting superior standards for the capturing of epic grandeur and he garnered eleven Academy Awards (2004) including Best director.

results.title: The Lord of the rings: the fellowship of the rings (Special extended edition) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Peter Jackson, Fran Walsh, Tim Sanders, New Line Cinema and Wingnut Films
results.brief_description: Iconic adaptation of J R R Tolkien’s fantasy epic, “The Lord of the rings: the fellowship of the rings” is the first instalment of the “Rings” trilogy. Director Peter Jackson (Heavenly creatures, The Frighteners, Meet the Feebles) went to incredible lengths to re-create Tolkien’s fantastical vision to the screen by building extensive sets in his native New Zealand and by employing a slew of gifted special effects artists. In short, Frodo Baggins, a kind-hearted and earnest hobbit, is entrusted with the gallant mission to return a powerful ring from whence it came - Mount Doom, the only place where it can be destroyed. Failure to do so will result in the destruction of the earth, as the powerful ring is capable of unleashing inestimable evil. Guided by Gandalf, a powerful wizard, Frodo is accompanied on his treacherous journey by three hobbit friends, a dwarf, an elf and several humans. This heroic quest invokes all the necessary thrills of an adventure picture, whilst satiating the exacting standards of an audience inured to CGI wizardry, and gratifying legions of zealous Tolkien fans. With ambitious battle scenes and stupendous set pieces, this grand and masterful cinematic spectacle kept most viewers utterly enthralled, whilst earning Jackson almost universal praise for capturing Tolkien’s mythopoeic narrative and elegiac tone.

results.title: The Lord of the rings: the fellowship of the ring
results.creator_credit: Peter Jackson, New Line Cinema, Wingnut Films, Fran Walsh and Tim Sanders
results.brief_description: Iconic adaptation of J R R Tolkien’s fantasy epic, “The Lord of the rings: the fellowship of the rings” is the first instalment of the “Rings” trilogy. Director Peter Jackson (Heavenly creatures, The Frighteners, Meet the Feebles) went to incredible lengths to re-create Tolkien’s fantastical vision to the screen, by building extensive realistic sets in his native New Zealand, and by employing a slew of gifted special effects artists. In short, Frodo Baggins, a kind-hearted and earnest hobbit, is entrusted with the gallant mission to return a powerful ring from whence it came - Mount Doom, the only place where it can be destroyed. Failure to do so will result in the destruction of the earth, as the powerful ring is capable of unleashing inestimable evil. Guided by Gandalf, a powerful wizard, Frodo is accompanied on his treacherous journey by three hobbit friends, a dwarf, an elf and several humans. This heroic quest invokes all the necessary thrills of an adventure picture, whilst satiating the exacting standards of an audience inured to CGI wizardry, and gratifying legions of zealous Tolkien fans. With ambitious battle scenes and stupendous set pieces, this grand and masterful cinematic spectacle kept most viewers utterly enthralled, whilst earning Jackson almost universal praise for capturing Tolkien’s mythopoeic narrative and elegiac tone.

results.title: The Lord Mayor
results.creator_credit: Chris McGill, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Who is at the centre of the administration of a big city? With this film the viewer spends a day in the company of the Lord Mayor of Sydney, Alderman Sir Nicholas Shehadie, OBE. Narrated by John Laws.

results.title: The Lorax (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Hawley Pratt, Isadore Freleng and DePatie-Freleng Enterprises
results.brief_description: Presents the story from the book “The Lorax” by Dr. Seuss. A fanciful tale with a serious theme: clean up the environment before it’s too late. In this delightful story the student is introduced to the needs of everyman. And the Lorax? Who is he and what does he do? Only Dr. Seuss can describe the creature - which he does with typical Seussian logic.

results.title: The Lopsided wheel
results.creator_credit: Bedrick Rogers, L. Richard Ellison and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Around Us”.
The development of the wheel is illustrated from its invention to its use in computer machinery. Wheels of all kinds are shown and their common relation to certain laws of energy. This film highlights the problems created by wheels in the United States and other industrialised nations where there are too many, and in underdeveloped countries where there are not enough.

results.title: The Looney, looney, looney Bugs Bunny movie
results.creator_credit: Isadore Freleng and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: A feature length film containing some of Friz Freleng’s award winning cartoons starring those wonderful cartoon character creations of Freleng’s including Bugs Bunny, Yosemite Sam, Pepe Le Pew, Porky Pig, Daffy Duck, Tweety Pie and Sylvester. The film is presented as part of an Award Ceremony honouring the classic Merrie Melodies and Looney Tunes characters beginning with Bugs Bunny in an Academy Award winning cartoon short “Knighty knight Bugs”. The program is then divided into three acts: Act I - “Satan’s waitin’” starring Yosemite Sam; Act II - “The Unmentionables” starring Bugs Bunny as Elegant Ness, co-starring Daffy Duck, Porky Pig, Tweety Pie and Sylvester along with the notorious Rocky and his gang; Act III - The Oswald Awards hosted by Bugs Bunny (a take on the Academy Awards) showing cartoon highlights of the nominees in their starring performances, including Big Bad Wolf and the Three little bops. Classic cartoons, great family entertainment. Majority of voice characterisations by Mel Blanc.

results.title: The Loon's necklace
results.brief_description: A re-creation of a legend of the Indians of British Colombia, using carved ceremonial masks of the Indians and animated drawings. The loon is a North American water bird. The story tells of Kelora, a blind medicine man. During a hard winter, his village suffers from famine, and is attacked by hungry wolves. Using his magic bow, Kelora is able to kill the wolves. In Spring, Kelora seeks out the loon, his “father”, and the loon gives him the power to see. In gratitude Kelora takes his most precious possession, a bead necklace, and throws it round the loon’s neck. That is how the loon came to get his collar of bright feathers.

results.title: The Loom never stops : a conversation with Thomas Ladgrove
results.creator_credit: Thomas Ladgrove and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: When Thomas Ladgrove started work at Brintons carpet factory in 1967, he was a ward of the state. He eventually started working with the loom and became the youngest weaver in Australia and England at age 18. He describes his work on the loom as well as staff morale when it became clear that Brintons was suffering, the subsequent rumours and worry and then the closure when the announcement to cease operations was made.
